required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Therapeutic Exploratory Study of Comparing Natamycin and Voriconazole to Treat Fungal Corneal Ulcer
clinical_study.official_title: Mycotic Ulcer Treatment Trial Therapeutic Exploratory Study

brief_summary.textblock: We evaluated whether voriconazole is a superior treatment to natamycin for filamentous fungal keratitis in a randomized, masked, controlled trial. This is a therapeutic exploratory study to investigate the safety and feasibility of conducting a larger study and to generate preliminary data.

detailed_description.textblock:
Fungal ulcers tend to have very poor outcomes with the most common treatments, amphotericin B and natamycin. There has been only a single randomized trial of anti-fungal therapy for fungal ulcers and no new medications have been approved by the FDA since the 1960s. There are studies that indicate that the newer triazoles, such as voriconazole, are more effective in vitro against filamentous fungi such as Aspergillus spp., a common cause of fungal keratitis1-3. Despite a number of case reports and in vitro studies, there has been no systematic attempt to determine whether it is more or less effective clinically than natamycin, the only commercially available FDA-approved agent. There is little data available for physicians to make an informed, evidence-based decision on choice of antifungal.
We evaluated whether voriconazole is a superior treatment to natamycin for filamentous fungal keratitis in a randomized, masked, controlled trial. This is a therapeutic exploratory study to investigate the safety and feasibility of conducting a larger study and to generate preliminary data. The primary outcome is visual acuity at 3 months from enrollment. A subset of patients will be followed at 4 years from enrollment.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Best Spectacle Corrected Visual Acuity (BSCVA) 3 Months After Enrollment, Adjusting for Enrollment BSCVA in a Multiple Linear Regression Model
primary_outcome.description: The primary efficacy endpoint was BSCVA at 3 months in the study eye, using a linear regression model with 3-month BSCVA measured in logMAR (logarithm of the Minimum Angle of Resolution) as the outcome variable and treatment arm (voriconazole vs natamycin) and enrollment logMAR BSCVA and corneal de-epithelialization (yes or no) as covariates.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Resolution of Epithelial Defect
secondary_outcome.description: Resolution of epithelial defect was defined as the absence of an epithelial defect with administration of fluorescein. The time to re-epithelialization was compared between the voriconazole and natamycin groups using the Cox proportional hazards model, adjusting for baseline epithelial defect size.

secondary_outcome.measure: Size of Infiltrate/Scar Post-treatment Was Analyzed in a Linear Regression Model Using Enrollment Infiltrate/Scar Size as a Covariate.
secondary_outcome.description: Size of infiltrate/scar post-treatment was analyzed in a linear regression model using enrollment infiltrate/scar size as a covariate. No differentiation was made between infiltrate and scar when measuring infiltrate/scar size (measured in mm). For analysis, infiltrate/scar size was characterized by the geometric mean of the longest dimension and the longest perpendicular.

secondary_outcome.measure: Subgroup Analysis - Best Spectacle-corrected Visual Acuity Examined by Voriconazole and Natamycin Treatment Arms in Subgroups of Fungal Ulcers (Fusarium Spp and Aspergillus Spp).
secondary_outcome.description: Two subgroup analyses were conducted by causative organism: 1) best spectacle-corrected visual acuity (BSCVA) by treatment arm among Fusarium ulcers; 2) best spectacle-corrected visual acuity (BSCVA) by treatment arm among Aspergillus ulcers.

secondary_outcome.measure: Best Hard Contact Lens-corrected Visual Acuity 3 Months After Enrollment in a Multiple Linear Regression Model With Enrollment Hard Contact Lens-corrected Visual Acuity as a Covariate
secondary_outcome.description: Best hard contact lens-corrected visual acuity 3 months after enrollment was evaluated in a multiple linear regression model with enrollment hard contact lens-corrected visual acuity as a covariate. Visual acuity is reported in logMAR (logarithm of the Minimum Angle of Resolution).

intervention.description: One drop of medication will be given every one hour while awake for one week. For another 2 weeks, one drop of medication should be given every 2 hours while awake

Voriconazole (VFENDÂ® I.V., Pfizer, New York, NY) will be prepared as a 1% solution. One drop of medication should be given every one hour while awake for one week. For another 2 weeks, one drop of medication should be given every 2 hours while awake
Corneal de-epithelialization at 1 week and 2 weeks from enrollment to increase epithelial penetration of antifungal medications.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Presence of a corneal ulcer at presentation
- Evidence of filamentous fungus on KOH (or Giemsa or any other stain) or culture
- The patient must be able to verbalize a basic understanding of the study after it is explained to the patient, as determined by physician examiner. This understanding must include a commitment to return for follow-up visits.
- Willingness to be treated as an in-patient or to be treated as an out-patient and come back every 48-72 hours to receive fresh medication for 3 weeks
- Appropriate consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Overlying epithelial defect < 0.5 mm at its greatest width at presentation
- Impending perforation
- Evidence of bacteria on Gram stain at the time of enrollment
- Evidence of acanthamoeba by stain
- Evidence of herpetic keratitis by history or exam
- Corneal scar not easily distinguishable from current ulcer
- Age less than 16 years (before 16th birthday)
- Bilateral ulcers
- Previous penetrating keratoplasty in the affected eye
- Pregnancy (by history or urine test) or breast-feeding (by history)
- Acuity worse than 6/60 (20/200) in the fellow eye (note that any acuity, uncorrected, corrected, pinhole, or BSCVA 6/60 or better qualifies for enrollment)
- Known allergy to study medications (antifungal or preservative)
- No light perception in the affected eye
- Not willing to participate

overall_official.affiliation: Proctor Foundation, University of California, San Francisco
Proctor Foundation, University of California, San Francisco

participant_flow.recruitment_details: From November 27, 2007 to May 12, 2008, all patients with a corneal ulcer presenting to Aravind Eye Hospitalâs cornea clinics in Madurai and Pondicherry, India, were evaluated for eligibility. The Aravind Eye Care System is both a primary and tertiary care eye hospital in South India with a well-established cornea subspecialty clinic.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: All patients with a corneal ulcer had corneal scrapings using a Kimura spatula for Gram stain and potassium hydroxide wet mount and had cultures plated on blood, chocolate, and potato dextrose agar. If all inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria were met, the patient was enrolled in the study.

group.title: Topical Natamycin With Corneal De-epithelialization
group.description: Topical natamycin with corneal de-epithelialization. Drug: Natamycin 5% One drop of medication every one hour while awake for one week. For another 2 weeks, one drop of medication every 2 hours while awake. Procedure/Surgery: Corneal de-epithelialization Corneal de-epithelialization at 1 week and 2 weeks from enrollment to increase epithelial penetration of antifungal medications.

group.title: Topical Natamycin Without Corneal De-epithelialization
group.description: Topical natamycin without corneal de-epithelialization. Drug: Natamycin 5% One drop of medication every one hour while awake for one week. For another 2 weeks, one drop of medication every 2 hours while awake.

group.title: Topical Voriconazole With Corneal De-epithelialization
group.description: Topical voriconazole with corneal de-epithelialization. Drug: Voriconazole Voriconazole prepared as a 1% solution. One drop of medication every one hour while awake for one week. For another 2 weeks, one drop of medication every 2 hours while awake. Procedure/Surgery: Corneal de-epithelialization Corneal de-epithelialization at 1 week and 2 weeks from enrollment to increase epithelial penetration of antifungal medications.

measure.title: Enrollment logMAR BSCVA
measure.description: Best spectacle-corrected visual acuity at time of enrollment measured in logMAR

outcome.title: Best Spectacle Corrected Visual Acuity (BSCVA) 3 Months After Enrollment, Adjusting for Enrollment BSCVA in a Multiple Linear Regression Model
outcome.description: The primary efficacy endpoint was BSCVA at 3 months in the study eye, using a linear regression model with 3-month BSCVA measured in logMAR (logarithm of the Minimum Angle of Resolution) as the outcome variable and treatment arm (voriconazole vs natamycin) and enrollment logMAR BSCVA and corneal de-epithelialization (yes or no) as covariates.

measure.title: Best Spectacle Corrected Visual Acuity (BSCVA) 3 Months After Enrollment, Adjusting for Enrollment BSCVA in a Multiple Linear Regression Model
measure.description: The primary efficacy endpoint was BSCVA at 3 months in the study eye, using a linear regression model with 3-month BSCVA measured in logMAR (logarithm of the Minimum Angle of Resolution) as the outcome variable and treatment arm (voriconazole vs natamycin) and enrollment logMAR BSCVA and corneal de-epithelialization (yes or no) as covariates.

analysis.method_desc: Multiple linear regression model adjusted for enrollment BSCVA and corneal de-epithelialization

outcome.title: Time to Resolution of Epithelial Defect
outcome.description: Resolution of epithelial defect was defined as the absence of an epithelial defect with administration of fluorescein. The time to re-epithelialization was compared between the voriconazole and natamycin groups using the Cox proportional hazards model, adjusting for baseline epithelial defect size.

group.title: Topical Voriconazole
group.description: Drug: Voriconazole Voriconazole prepared as a 1% solution. One drop of medication every one hour while awake for one week. For another 2 weeks, one drop of medication every 2 hours while awake

group.title: Topical Natamycin
group.description: Drug: Natamycin 5% One drop of medication every one hour while awake for one week. For another 2 weeks, one drop of medication every 2 hours while awake

measure.title: Time to Resolution of Epithelial Defect
measure.description: Resolution of epithelial defect was defined as the absence of an epithelial defect with administration of fluorescein. The time to re-epithelialization was compared between the voriconazole and natamycin groups using the Cox proportional hazards model, adjusting for baseline epithelial defect size.

outcome.title: Size of Infiltrate/Scar Post-treatment Was Analyzed in a Linear Regression Model Using Enrollment Infiltrate/Scar Size as a Covariate.
outcome.description: Size of infiltrate/scar post-treatment was analyzed in a linear regression model using enrollment infiltrate/scar size as a covariate. No differentiation was made between infiltrate and scar when measuring infiltrate/scar size (measured in mm). For analysis, infiltrate/scar size was characterized by the geometric mean of the longest dimension and the longest perpendicular.

group.title: Topical Voriconazole
group.description: Drug: Voriconazole Voriconazole prepared as a 1% solution. One drop of medication every one hour while awake for one week. For another 2 weeks, one drop of medication every 2 hours while awake. Note that 9 patients in the voriconazole arm had home visits conducted as their 3 month follow-up visit and scar size was not able to be obtained for these patients so they are not included in these analyses.

group.title: Topical Natamycin
group.description: Drug: Natamycin 5% One drop of medication every one hour while awake for one week. For another 2 weeks, one drop of medication every 2 hours while awake. Note that 5 patients in the natamycin arm had home visits conducted as their 3 month follow-up visit and scar size was not able to be obtained for these patients so they are not included in these analyses.

measure.title: Size of Infiltrate/Scar Post-treatment Was Analyzed in a Linear Regression Model Using Enrollment Infiltrate/Scar Size as a Covariate.
measure.description: Size of infiltrate/scar post-treatment was analyzed in a linear regression model using enrollment infiltrate/scar size as a covariate. No differentiation was made between infiltrate and scar when measuring infiltrate/scar size (measured in mm). For analysis, infiltrate/scar size was characterized by the geometric mean of the longest dimension and the longest perpendicular.

outcome.title: Subgroup Analysis - Best Spectacle-corrected Visual Acuity Examined by Voriconazole and Natamycin Treatment Arms in Subgroups of Fungal Ulcers (Fusarium Spp and Aspergillus Spp).
outcome.description: Two subgroup analyses were conducted by causative organism: 1) best spectacle-corrected visual acuity (BSCVA) by treatment arm among Fusarium ulcers; 2) best spectacle-corrected visual acuity (BSCVA) by treatment arm among Aspergillus ulcers.
outcome.population: This analysis looks at two different subgroups - Fusarium ulcers and Aspergillus ulcers. There were 44 Fusaruim ulcers enrolled in this trial and analyzed here, 23 of which were randomized to voriconazole and 21 to natamycin. There were 19 Aspergillus ulcers analyzed here, 8 of which were randomized to voriconazole and 11 to natamycin.

class.title: BSCVA Fusarium ulcers (n=23 vori; n=21 nata)
BSCVA Aspergillus ulcers (n=8 vori; n=11 nata)

analysis.groups_desc: Best spectacle-corrected visual acuity (BSCVA) was examined in a linear regression model with enrollment BSCVA and treatment arm as covariates among a subgroup of ulcers caused by Fusarium spp.
Best spectacle-corrected visual acuity (BSCVA) was evaluated in a linear regression model with enrollment BSCVA and treatment arm as covariates in a subgroup of ulcers caused by Aspergillus spp.

outcome.title: Best Hard Contact Lens-corrected Visual Acuity 3 Months After Enrollment in a Multiple Linear Regression Model With Enrollment Hard Contact Lens-corrected Visual Acuity as a Covariate
outcome.description: Best hard contact lens-corrected visual acuity 3 months after enrollment was evaluated in a multiple linear regression model with enrollment hard contact lens-corrected visual acuity as a covariate. Visual acuity is reported in logMAR (logarithm of the Minimum Angle of Resolution).

event.sub_title: No resolution of epithelial defect by 21 days
event.description: Reepithelialization was defined as an epithelial defect of less than 0.5 mm with administration of fluorescein.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
